title: GitHub authentication repeats indefinitely
body: Note, this is **not a duplicate** of #253124. This issue is not related to Copilot Chat, although it is related to Copilot authentication. This is a cross-post of [an issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-azurefunctions/issues/4691#issuecomment-3225100164) I reported in the VS Code Azure project, since it is related to GitHub Copilot as well. This is a bit of a complicated issue, so I'll try to explain it. First, the symptom that I see is in VSCode, when I have the Azure Resources extension installed, it can get into a state where it continuously repeats GitHub authentication. Yes, I know Azure and GitHub are not directly related, but this is what I'm seeing. The messages are shown in the VSCode Output panel for `GitHub Authentication`, and they look like the following and are repeated continuously. ```txt 2025-08-19 16:54:18.347 [info] Getting sessions for all scopes... 2025-08-19 16:54:18.347 [info] Got 5 sessions for ... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.675 [info] Getting sessions for all scopes... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.678 [info] Got 5 sessions for ... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.683 [info] Getting sessions for read:user,repo,user:email,workflow... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.684 [info] Got 1 sessions for read:user,repo,user:email,workflow... ``` This is a problem because it ends up using the GitHub API, which can expire your rate limit. You can check the usage via a command like `curl -H "Authorization: token " https://api.github.com/rate_limit`. Which shows something like the following (I've excluded the uninteresting bits): ```txt { "resources": { "core": { "limit": 5000, "used": 3376, "remaining": 1624, "reset": 1755591629 }, ⠇ "code_scanning_upload": { "limit": 5000, "used": 3376, "remaining": 1624, "reset": 1755591629 }, ⠇ }, "rate": { "limit": 5000, "used": 3376, "remaining": 1624, "reset": 1755591629 } } ``` I've been able to temporarily solve this problem by clicking on the Accounts icon in the bottom-left in VSCode, going to my Microsoft account (the one I use for logging into Azure), and logging out. If I then go to the Azure Resources panel it says I need to `Sign in to Azure`. If I do that, it logs in successfully and the problem is no longer happening. **But**, the problem resurfaces at some time later. I'm not sure what causes it to start again. I mentioned the Azure Resources extension as a problem, but I believe this may happen with any Azure extension, like Azure Functions, Azure Databases, etc. I also don't know why these Azure extensions have interactions with GitHub authentication. One thing I did notice is that if I go to Account in VSCode, click on my Microsoft account, and then click on `Manage Trusted Extensions` then a list of trusted extensions is shown, one of which is `GitHub Copilot Chat`, so this implies at least some connection between this account an GitHub. See the screenshots below. Let me know if there is anything I can do to help investigate this problem more.

title: GitHub authentication repeats indefinitely, using up rate limit
body: This is a cross-post of [an issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-azurefunctions/issues/4691#issuecomment-3225100164) I reported in the VS Code Azure project, since it is related to GitHub Copilot as well. This is a bit of a complicated issue, so I'll try to explain it. First, the symptom that I see is in VSCode, when I have the Azure Resources extension installed, it can get into a state where it continuously repeats GitHub authentication. Yes, I know Azure and GitHub are not directly related, but this is what I'm seeing. The messages are shown in the VSCode Output panel for `GitHub Authentication`, and they look like the following and are repeated continuously. ```txt 2025-08-19 16:54:18.347 [info] Getting sessions for all scopes... 2025-08-19 16:54:18.347 [info] Got 5 sessions for ... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.675 [info] Getting sessions for all scopes... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.678 [info] Got 5 sessions for ... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.683 [info] Getting sessions for read:user,repo,user:email,workflow... 2025-08-19 16:54:54.684 [info] Got 1 sessions for read:user,repo,user:email,workflow... ``` This is a problem because it ends up using the GitHub API, which can expire your rate limit. You can check the usage via a command like `curl -H "Authorization: token " https://api.github.com/rate_limit`. Which shows something like the following (I've excluded the uninteresting bits): ```txt { "resources": { "core": { "limit": 5000, "used": 3376, "remaining": 1624, "reset": 1755591629 }, ⠇ "code_scanning_upload": { "limit": 5000, "used": 3376, "remaining": 1624, "reset": 1755591629 }, ⠇ }, "rate": { "limit": 5000, "used": 3376, "remaining": 1624, "reset": 1755591629 } } ``` I've been able to temporarily solve this problem by clicking on the Accounts icon in the bottom-left in VSCode, going to my Microsoft account (the one I use for logging into Azure), and logging out. If I then go to the Azure Resources panel it says I need to `Sign in to Azure`. If I do that, it logs in successfully and the problem is no longer happening. **But**, the problem resurfaces at some time later. I'm not sure what causes it to start again. I mentioned the Azure Resources extension as a problem, but I believe this may happen with any Azure extension, like Azure Functions, Azure Databases, etc. I also don't know why these Azure extensions have interactions with GitHub authentication. One thing I did notice is that if I go to Account in VSCode, click on my Microsoft account, and then click on `Manage Trusted Extensions` then a list of trusted extensions is shown, one of which is `GitHub Copilot Chat`, so this implies at least some connection between this account an GitHub. See the screenshots below. Let me know if there is anything I can do to help investigate this problem more.

labels.name: under-discussion

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I've been noticing that I start typing a terminal command, and there is some lag in when characters actually show up. I suspect it's related to suggestions

Tried to capture it here. I type `asdf` very quickly, almost all at once. But you see `a` show up, then a pause, then the rest of the characters appear.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4b5f2d7a-e4c6-4869-8650-437466cf865f

Here you see the pause and the suggest widget show, then the rest of the chars

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2abc24de-a73c-4a20-ab86-41261bcd78ff


I don't think I see this in stable

I took a renderer and EH profile and I don't think they show anything interesting. Definitely nothing in renderer but here's the EH profile

title: add internal filing option to issueReporter
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

Fixes: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260182
corresponding addition of the field for copilot chat: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/799

Adds a field into the IssueReporterData that allows the passing of a `privateUri` that represents an internal repository that the user may want to file into for when working on code that may contain sensitive material.

Also contains some structural improvements that organize things a bit and prevent button(s) from getting into broken states. No longer any reliance on context keys or entitlements, just the gh token, and `privateUri` which makes this somewhat extensible

cc/ @justschen

title: Disallow invalid states for `ChatSessionItem`
body:
This combines the state info into a single type so that you cannot create invalid states, such as `InProgress` with an endTime

In the future this can also be used to more neatly add other metadata, such as a failure reason string for failed sessions

title: Use terminals that are not in use
body: Type: Feature Request The chat does not use the same terminal where the app is running, so it prefers to open a new terminal and run the program when it is already running. Also, if it is possible, let the developer select the terminal to use (or use a new terminal). This would be extremely useful. Sometimes, chat tries opening a terminal to run a program and it does not run because the environment selected is not correct for the new terminal and it does not found the packages or libraries (from imports). title: GitHub Copilot fails with "Invalid copilot token: missing token: 403" after sign-in

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: After signing into GitHub Copilot in VS Code, the extension fails to initialize and shows the following in the logs: ``` 025-08-27 23:10:47.916 [info] [certificates] Removed 12 expired certificates 2025-08-27 23:10:48.602 [info] [auth] Invalid copilot token: missing token: 403 ``` The Copilot Chat panel also fails to load and sometimes prompts: Copilot failed to get ready. Please ensure you are signed in to GitHub and that the extension GitHub.copilot-chat is installed and enabled. Occasionally, a pop-up appears : Contact Support. Source: GitHub Copilot --- **Steps to Reproduce** 1. Install VS Code (latest stable). 2. Install both **GitHub Copilot** and **GitHub Copilot Chat** extensions. 3. Sign in via `GitHub: Sign in` from Command Palette. 4. Attempt to use Copilot or open Copilot Chat. --- **Expected Behavior** Copilot should authenticate successfully and provide suggestions/chat without authentication errors. --- **Actual Behavior** Authentication fails with a 403 error in logs, and Copilot Chat cannot be used. --- **Logs / Screenshots** **What I’ve Tried** - Signing out and signing back in to GitHub. - Resetting Copilot authentication (`GitHub Copilot: Reset Authentication`). - Reinstalling both extensions. - Clearing global storage folders for `github.copilot` and `github.copilot-chat`. - Removing OS-stored GitHub tokens from Credential Manager/Keychain. - Reloading VS Code. **VS Code version:** 1.103.2 **OS**: Windows 11 **Copilot extension version**: 1.350.0 **Copilot Chat extension version**: 0.30.3 **GitHub account type**: Individual **Network**: Direct

body: **VS Code Version**: 1.104.0-insiders **OS Version**: macOS Sequoia 15.6.1 **Screenreader**: VoiceOver **Extensions Installed**: Put together an extension to quickly demo the bare VS Code UI features without our normal SDK and extension wrappers. "a11y-kit" (https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=MicroFish.accessibility-testkit) **Repro Steps**: 1. Install `a11y-kit` from VS Code Marketplace 2. F1 > `a11y-kit: Select UI feature for accessibility testing` > `Display Tree View` 3. While the tree view is empty, tab to the collapsible toggle icon using keyboard **Expected**: While the collapsible toggle is inactive, the keyboard should not be able to select the icon. **Actual**: Collapsible toggle is selectable via keyboard. **Original Source**: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-azurefunctions/issues/3818

title: Bad design: Contact Support (Reason: '')

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: When directing a user to contact GitHub support - without exception, provide a reason. Seriously, what I see today doesn't even rise to the level of an error message, except for the detail that things are not working and no reason is given. All I have is VS Code directing me to a generic Github support page. No reason why. Maybe it's tied to Copilot not working? And the support page does nothing to indicate why I might need to reach out to support. No indication of problems with the account, so... why would I be directed there? If I talk to support, will they help? "Hi, why are we talking?" That's insane. Give reasons - always. They don't necessarily need to be helpful reasons, but they do need to do more to narrow the problem than the text "Contact Support", and can do more to inform support of what's going on than the user question of "why am I calling you?"

title: Implements prefixed uuids for eventIds and suggestionIds
[WIP] Fix context menu appearing on History parent node in chat sessions
body:
- [x] Analyze the problem: Context menu appears on History parent node in chat sessions view
- [x] Identify root cause: `showContextMenu` method doesn't exclude 'show-history' node like `openChatSession` does
- [x] Review existing code patterns for handling 'show-history' node
- [ ] Implement fix: Add early return in `showContextMenu` method for 'show-history' node
- [ ] Test the change to ensure it works correctly
- [ ] Verify no regression in existing functionality

**Problem**: Right-clicking on the "History" parent node in chat sessions view incorrectly shows context menu commands. The "History" parent node (`id: 'show-history'`) should not display context menu actions since it's a structural/organizational node.

**Solution**: Add a check in `showContextMenu` method to exclude the "History" parent node, following the same pattern already used in `openChatSession` method.

title: [WIP] Remove index from local chat session IDs
body:
Analyzing the VS Code chat sessions local provider sessionId generation issue and planning the fix.

## Plan: Remove index from local chat session IDs

- [x] **Understand the current implementation**
  - Found sessionId generation in `LocalChatSessionsProvider.provideChatSessionItems` method (line 444)
  - Current pattern: `local-${editorInfo.group.id}-${index}` where index is iteration order
  - This makes sessionIds unstable when editor order changes

- [ ] **Analyze requirements and choose stable identifier**
  - Need to replace `index` with stable identifier based on editor properties
  - Consider using `editor.typeId` or hash of `editorKey` for uniqueness
  - Ensure identifier is consistent across sessions

- [ ] **Implement the fix**
  - Replace `${index}` with stable identifier in sessionId generation
  - Update any related code that might depend on this pattern

- [ ] **Test the changes**
  - Verify compilation works
  - Test basic functionality to ensure sessionIds are generated correctly
  - Ensure no breaking changes to existing behavior

- [ ] **Validate and document**
  - Ensure sessionId uniqueness within the same group

title: Always show chat widget entry first in chat sessions and initialize on demand
body:
## Problem

The chat sessions view only displayed the chat widget entry when a chat widget was already active in the panel. Additionally, when the widget entry was present, it could be moved from its intended first position due to timestamp-based sorting, creating an inconsistent user experience where the main chat interface wasn't always easily discoverable at the top of the list.

## Solution

This PR modifies the chat sessions view to always show the chat widget entry as the first item, regardless of whether a chat widget currently exists or its timestamp. When users click on the entry, it either focuses the existing widget or initializes a new one on demand.

### Key Changes

**Always Show Widget Entry First**
- Modified `LocalChatSessionsProvider.provideChatSessionItems()` to always include the chat widget session entry
- Fixed ordering logic to ensure widget entry always appears first by separating it from timestamp-based sorting
- Entry displays as "Chat View" with placeholder state when no widget exists
- Maintains proper state and metadata when widget is active

**On-Demand Initialization**
- Updated `SessionsViewPane.openChatSession()` to handle widget entry clicks without an existing widget
- Opens the chat view which automatically creates and registers the widget
- Preserves existing behavior for active widgets

**Telemetry & Analytics**
- Added GDPR-compliant telemetry tracking for widget initialization from sessions view
- Tracks both successful and failed initialization attempts
- Provides insights into chat widget discoverability and usage patterns

### Before vs After

**Before:**
```typescript
if (chatWidget) {
    sessions.push(widgetSession);
}
// Widget only visible when it exists
processSessionsWithTimeGrouping(normalSessions); // Could move widget from first position
```

**After:**
```typescript
// Always create and show widget session entry
sessions.push(widgetSession);

// Keep widget first, sort only editor sessions
const widgetSessions = sessions.filter(s => s.sessionType === 'widget');
const editorSessions = sessions.filter(s => s.sessionType === 'editor');
processSessionsWithTimeGrouping(editorSessions);
return [...widgetSessions, ...editorSessions, historyNode];
```

### Benefits

- **Better Discoverability**: Chat widget option always visible and consistently positioned
- **Improved User Experience**: One-click access without needing to initialize elsewhere
- **Predictable UI**: Entry always appears first, regardless of widget state or timestamps
- **Performance**: On-demand loading reduces startup overhead
- **Backward Compatibility**: Existing workflows unchanged

This change significantly improves the chat widget's accessibility and provides a consistent user experience while maintaining all existing functionality.
